text.p: The following are the main stories from Friday's Albanian newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy:
- The editorial quotes the Dutch representative at the European Union as asking the Albanian government to organise "fresh and fair elections within the shortest time possible".
- Thousands of protestors in Tirana attempted to reach the main Skanderbeg Square after an anti-goverment demonstration on Thursday but police managed to disperse them.
- Neritan Ceka, leader of the right-wing Democratic Alliance party, said the state was paying $470 a month to some 2,000 riot policemen deployed to quell recent unrest around the country.
- Tritan Shehu, leader of the ruling Democratic party, said President Sali Berisha had managed to avoid bloodshed in the country.
- Fourteen ruling party deputies have asked for the government's resignation.
- Vefa Holding started to reimburse small investors who have put up to $5,000 into the company.
- Adoption of this year's state budget has been delayed because the International Monetary Fund does not agree with the Albanian government's proposals.
- Students in the southern town of Vlore have started a hunger strike asking for the government's resignation and complete reimbursement of losses incurred by the collapse of pyramid schemes.
- Protests were held in the southern towns of Tepelene, Sarande, Kucove, Fier and Vlore.
- Police in Vlore arrested the wife of a top manager of the failed Gjallica pyramid scheme.
- Kamberi, another company that has offered high returns to investors, announced it would start reimbursing depositors from March 1.

- First division soccer clubs said they wanted matches to resume after the month-long cancellation of matches because of the unrest in the country. They asked police to provide security for the teams.
